about.metaDescription: Understand Molthub.bot's neutral methodology for Moltbot reliability signals, covering MSI(TM) tiers, evidence sources, and update cadence. Descriptive only.
about.title: Moltbot Methodology
about.intro: Molthub.bot is a non-official, community-driven reliability signal layer for Moltbot skills. The goal is to document stability, survivability, and viability signals in a neutral, engineering-first tone.
about.scopePara1: Signals are compiled from user reports, reproducible setups, and operator notes. We focus on behavioral consistency, configuration sensitivity, and environment variance.
about.scopePara2: The content is descriptive only. It does not prescribe or restrict usage decisions.
about.msiPara1: MSI is presented as a single score for quick scanning. Tier labels indicate relative stability at the time of the latest update.
about.msiPara2: A skill can move between Stable, Risky, and Unstable tiers as configuration, environment, or implementation details change.
about.radarPara: Radar entries highlight elevated risk or degraded behavior when specific conditions are observed. Each entry lists affected skills and the latest update time.
about.disclaimerPara: Molthub.bot does not provide warranties. The signals may be incomplete or become unstable as upstream changes occur. Validate in your own environment before critical use.

rename.metaDescription: Explanation of why Clawdbot was renamed to Moltbot, including naming alignment, clarity, and long-term viability. Neutral, engineering-first context.
rename.title: Why Clawdbot Became Moltbot
rename.intro: This note documents the rename from Clawdbot to Moltbot in a neutral, engineering-first tone. It is descriptive only.
primaryReasons: Alignment: the new name matches the Moltbot skill ecosystem naming.
Clarity: reduced ambiguity in documentation, URLs, and references.
Viability: a simpler name improves long-term consistency and recall.
impactItems: All reliability signals continue under the same neutral methodology.
Data sources remain local JSON, unchanged in structure.
Legacy references can be mapped to the new name without drift.
rename.timelinePara: The rename is effective as of 2026-01-29. Earlier mentions of Clawdbot should be considered equivalent to Moltbot for documentation and signal tracking purposes.
rename.terminologyPara: "Clawdbot" is now a legacy label. "Moltbot" is the active name used across all reliability, stability, survivability, and viability signals.

installGuides.keywordLine: Keywords: Moltbot, Clawdbot, Windows, macOS, Mac mini, Linux, Docker, NPM, install, setup
installGuides.title: Most reliable Moltbot / Clawdbot install guides (Windows / macOS / Linux)
installGuides.subtitle: Curated authoritative articles and videos for fast setup, plus official docs and general resources.
installGuides.intro: This page captures install/setup search traffic and routes you to /install, /security, and /providers for validation and rollout.

labels.searchHint: No stable link yet. Search YouTube for:

windows.summary: Best for users installing Moltbot/Clawdbot on Windows. Start with NPM, then use WSL2 or Docker for compatibility.

mac.summary: Best for macOS and Mac mini users, especially Apple Silicon. Use NPM for speed and Docker for isolation.

linux.summary: Best for servers and production. Use Docker Compose for rollout and add monitoring/security for production.
linux.recommended: Recommended paths: Docker Compose / server / production

faq.question: Should I install Moltbot/Clawdbot with NPM or Docker?
faq.answer: For beginners, start with NPM for a shorter install/setup path. Use Docker for dependency isolation or multi-instance setups. Production typically prefers Docker Compose for rollbacks and ops.

faq.question: Is WSL2 recommended on Windows? What if I don't want WSL?
faq.answer: WSL2 improves compatibility. If you avoid WSL, use native Windows NPM install and switch to Docker if dependencies become unstable.

faq.question: Any macOS / Mac mini (Apple Silicon) considerations?
faq.answer: Use the recommended Node version. If you hit native dependency issues, Docker helps standardize the environment on Apple Silicon.

faq.question: Minimum security guidance for Linux production?
faq.answer: Use least-privilege runtime, isolate networks, enable audit logging, and store API keys outside repos and images.

faq.question: Where should API keys live to avoid GitHub leaks?
faq.answer: Use environment variables or a secrets manager. Avoid committing .env or config files and scan before pushing.
